Up until 70 years ago, Latino students were forced into segregated schools due to unjust laws that prevented people of color from attending traditionally white schools. Let us celebrate the 70th anniversary of Mendez v. Westminster, which ended the policy of de facto segregation throughout the nation and set up the precedent for Brown v. Board of Education. 

Now 94% of seniors at Mendez High School, a predominately Latino school, are graduating this year. When I took charge of this school as mayor, only 48% of seniors graduated. This is the promise of Mendez, providing an environment where all students can have a quality education and a bright future ahead.

status_message:
Celebremos la Independencia de nuestra nación complacidos, sabiendo que somos un faro de promesa, esperanza y libertad para muchos, en un mundo en el que abunda la tiranía y la opresión.

Debemos sentirnos orgullosos de que, el cimiento de nuestra patria sea la premisa " todos los hombres son iguales". Más orgullosos aún, de que, a pesar de que los Padres de nuestra nación no dijeron específicamente, mujeres, afroamericanos, indios nativos u otro europeo sin tierras, a través de nuestra historia nos hemos esforzado por lograr "una unión cada vez más perfecta", luchando para hacer realidad esa noción básica de la existencia humana.

 Nos convertimos en una "unión más perfecta" cuando la esclavitud fue abolida e incorporamos a nuestra Constitución,  la Enmienda 14 y después la Enmienda 19, que otorga a todos los ciudadanos igualdad ante la Ley y a las mujeres, el derecho al voto.

 Más tarde, el Acta de Derechos Civiles, el Acta sobre Derecho al Sufragio y el movimiento femenil, dieron un significado real a la  frase "todos los hombres" frente a la noción más limitada de nuestros antepasados y otorgaron más legitimidad a nuestra democracia.

La decisión de la Suprema Corte sobre la Igualdad ante el Matrimonio, representa un paso más hacia adelante, en lo que debe ser nuestra lucha constante por expandir la libertad y "la búsqueda de la felicidad" para todos.

Debemos, no obstante, celebrar nuestros progresos con vigorosa vigilancia, ante las amenazas a nuestra libertad. Los atroces asesinatos de nueve inocentes personas de color, en la iglesia "Mother Emanuel" A.M.E., son un recordatorio del odio racial y de la intolerancia  persistentes en muchos individuos. Los comentarios obtusos sobre los inmigrantes mexicanos, hechos por un bufón narcisista, candidato presidencial, deben ser confrontados, sin importar  quienes sean el blanco de esa retórica de odio.

En este día glorioso, mientras nos regocijamos por la fundación de nuestra Patria, no nos permitamos "dormir en nuestros laureles". ¡Nuestra lucha por crear "una unión más perfecta" no ha terminado!

 Para aquellos que dirían, en respuesta, "ama o abandona América", replicaríamos,  en este día maravilloso: "América, te amo y quiero que seas todo lo que nosotros aspiramos a ser"

 ¡Feliz cumpleaños América adorada!

 Antonio Villaraigosa

Let us celebrate our nation's independence reveling in the knowledge that we are a beacon of hope, promise and liberty to so many in  a world rife with tyranny and oppression.

We should be proud of our nation's founding on the premise that "all men are created equal". Prouder still, that although our nation's founding fathers did not mean women, blacks, Native Americans or other non-landowning Europeans. We have throughout our history strived to be " a more perfect union" struggling to realize that basic notion of human existence.

We became "a more perfect union" when we abolished slavery, passed the 14th Amendment and later the 19th Amendment to our Constitution  giving all our citizens equal protection under the law and women the right to vote.

Later the Civil Rights Act, the Voting Rights Acts and the women's movement gave real meaning to our forefather's limited notion of "all men" and gave our democracy more legitimacy.

The Supreme Court decision on marriage equality is another step forward in what must be a never ending quest to expand liberty and "the pursuit of happiness" for all.

We must however celebrate our progress with vigorous vigilance in the face of threats to our freedoms. The heinous murder of nine innocent black congregants  at  "Mother Emanuel " A.M.E. Church is a reminder of the residual racial hate and intolerance that still exists in too many.  The bigoted comments about Mexican immigrants by a narcissistic and buffoon-like presidential candidate, must be challenged regardless of who is the target of such hate speech.

So on this glorious day as we rejoice in our nation's founding let us not rest on our laurels, our struggle to create a "more perfect union" is still not done! 

To those who would say in response, " America love it or leave it" we say on this wonderful day, America I love you and want you to be all that we have held ourselves to be!

Happy Birthday my  beloved America!

Antonio Villaraigosa

Re: The Senate's passage of the immigration bill

Today marks a very significant step towards reimagining our broken immigration system into one that stimulates our economy and ensures that everyone plays by the same set of rules.

I applaud the hard work and consensus building demonstrated by the team of Senators who found common ground for the good of the country. And I'm happy the Senate has outlined a fair and achievable pathway to citizenship for the 11 million undocumented immigrants living in the shadows.  

We have a long way to go, and I urge the House of Representatives to stay in Washington, D.C. and pass the Senate's bill immediately.

Today, we have taken another momentous step on the path to full equality and dignity for all Californians and all Americans.  By striking down the Defense of Marriage Act, the Supreme Court has affirmed a basic American truth:  bigotry and bias have no place in our laws.  And with the Court's decision on Prop 8, California is poised to become the thirteenth state in America with full marriage equality. 

Today, we celebrate a victory for love and fairness, a victory for same-sex couples who only want to follow their hearts and marry the person they love.  As we move closer to a more perfect union, we will continue to make our case:  if we truly believe in family values, we should value all families.

My statement on U.S. Supreme Court's Affordable Care Act decision:

“Today’s ruling by the Supreme Court to uphold the basic provisions of the Affordable Care Act is a historic step forward for our country. Healthcare for each and every individual is not a privilege; it’s a right. This morning’s decision is a victory for all Americans, and I could not be prouder.

By upholding the Affordable Care Act the Supreme Court ensured 3.1 million young people – including 435,000 young Californians – will maintain their coverage. The Court’s ruling protects Americans with preexisting conditions and provides them with access to the safe and secure healthcare options that were once out of reach. By ruling that those people who can afford to buy insurance have an obligation to do so, the Court has reaffirmed the bedrock principle of personal responsibility. And most importantly, the Court’s ruling moves our nation one step closer to the ultimate goal of providing healthcare for all. More than 30 million Americans will gain affordable health care with the enactment of this bill. This is a momentous achievement that should be rightly celebrated.

Despite today’s victory, our work is not done. America still spends more than any other nation for health insurance. The Affordable Care Act provides important protections to curb the skyrocketing cost of healthcare and lessen the impact on the nation’s budget. In fact, according to official estimates, the law will lower the federal deficit by $143 billion by 2019. It is now incumbent on our nation’s leaders to ensure the successful implementation of this bill. We must halt the opponents of progress who seek to “repeal and replace” this important step towards universal coverage.

I applaud the Supreme Court’s leadership and decision to put the American people ahead of partisan politics. Their ruling to uphold the Affordable Care Act reaffirms our country’s commitment to the health and financial security of our people.”

My statement regarding Congress reaching an agreement on a transportation bill that includes America Fast Forward: 

"America Fast Forward is a path-breaking program that will dramatically accelerate transportation projects across the country.

I applaud Congress for including America Fast Forward in the agreement to reauthorize the nation’s surface transportation programs. I specifically want to thank Majority Leader Reid, Chairman Boxer, Ranking Member Inhofe, Chairman Mica, and Ranking Member Rahall for their far-sighted leadership in crafting the agreement and moving forward with much-needed investments in our country's roads, bridges and rail lines.

The Surface Transportation Bill will preserve 2 million jobs. With the inclusion of America Fast Forward, it will put close to an additional million Americans to work.

Working in partnership with the US Conference of Mayors, we assembled a broad, bipartisan coalition, including nearly 200 mayors and both the AFL-CIO and the US Chamber of Commerce, to bring America Fast Forward to fruition.

America Fast Forward expands an existing program – the Transportation Infrastructure Finance and Innovation Act (TIFIA) program – to give cities access to low-interest financing with flexible terms for their projects.

With America Fast Forward in place, cities across America will be able to speed up the construction of locally funded road and rail projects and get our economy moving again.

All of our proposals were included in the bill and we greatly appreciate Congress' support for these common-sense ideas.

Here in Los Angeles, this agreement on the Surface Transportation reauthorization and America Fast Forward will mean more jobs for Angelenos and will make it possible for us to accelerate our vision of a 21st century transportation network."

status_message:
I am heartened by today’s Supreme Court decision to strike down key elements of Arizona’s controversial SB 1070. The Supreme Court rightly upheld the bedrock constitutional principle that the federal government alone has the power to regulate immigration. It is clear that the Obama Administration and the Department of Justice were right to challenge this law.
 
But today’s ruling must be seen as only a partial victory. The Supreme Court’s decision does allow Arizona to implement the law’s most problematic and potentially most harmful section: the ‘papers please’ provision.
 
By requiring police officers to demand documents of anyone they suspect of being in the country without authorization, Arizona risks creating a culture of fear and suspicion. Implementation of the law will undermine the trust between the police and the public, driving a wedge between police officers and the community they serve. The papers please provision opens the door for racial profiling, and I believe it will be impossible to implement this law without discrimination. This will just invite further litigation.
 
In today’s decision, the Supreme Court rightly drew attention to the lasting contributions that immigrants have made to this country. We need a sensible and humane national immigration policy. We do not need a confusing patchwork of 50 state laws. It is time for Congress to act. It is time to pass the DREAM ACT and it is time to enact comprehensive immigration reform. We need a national solution to this national challenge.

My statement in response to President Obama’s action to end deportation of young immigrants:

“By ending the deportation of certain young immigrants and making them eligible to work in this country, President Obama has taken a bold step in the direction of a more humane and more sensible immigration policy. His action today upholds some of America’s most cherished values: our belief in opportunity and fairness and our tradition of openness and inclusion. Crucially with his decision, the President has also protected young immigrants, many of whom have been here since they were infants and have spent their whole lives in this country. Instead of fearing deportation, instead of facing the prospect of being separated from their loved ones, hundreds of thousands of young people can now do what generations of their predecessors have done. They can contribute their energy and enthusiasm and their dreams and determination to their new home and help drive the future prosperity and growth of the United States.

After an extended and frustrating impasse in our national immigration debate, President Obama has led the way and pointed us in the right direction. But this is only a first step and much still needs to be done. Now it is up to Congress. Let’s expand the circle of opportunity even more and finally pass the DREAM ACT. Let’s finally achieve comprehensive immigration reform.”
